item.name: 10 Days in Europe
item.comment: I like this family game but even I think it could have been presented better. The board is simply too small and detracts from the fun of the game for everyone. And the colors are too similiar even for players with no color vision issues. Jay T., this is fixable and a fun family game can emerge.

item.name: 1830: Railways & Robber Barons
item.comment: This is one of the few long games I am always willing to play because there is much to do to keep you involved.

item.name: 6 nimmt!
item.comment: A fast, fun filler that is great for 5-6 players that can still provide a bit of tension if you let it.

item.name: Ab die Post!
item.comment: Very dated and geared for younger players, except you have to open the movement shaker and change the tiny beads based on number of players. So it's not for children!?

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: I love finding gamers who have never played this before. It's like leading them into that lost city of ... whatever?! You know what I mean.

item.name: Africa
item.comment: Nice, light, family-fare that allows your brain a bit of rest yet keeps you pleasantly occupied.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment: I like this game more with each playing; however, a game is easily ruined by one player's inexperince or lack of skill. So much has to happen right from the start and continue building each turn. And positioning on the board is a major aspect of the game, creating opportunities for yourself while limiting those of your opponents, watching the distribution of resources carefully so you don't come up short at the end while someone else is allowed to go unchallenged across the board with an abundance of unshared resources.

item.name: Airline
item.comment: Acquire derivitive which is not a bad thing.

item.name: Aladdin's Dragons
item.comment: I never win this. My wife, my friend's fiance who only barely likes and plays games, just beat the heck out of me every time we play this. I don't get it. I can't seem to find a nitche on the board that doesn't bring someone into heated contention with me...

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: I like what has been done with the game. It is not simply a re-theming as was done with Atlantic Star. But I would not again play this with more than 4 players. There is simply way too much down time with nothing to do but wait. You can't even plan ahead because so much will change before it gets around to your turn again so all you will do is get frustrated. But for 3 - 4 players it is great fun. Stimmt So! could be played with 5 or 6 because lacking the enhancements of this newer version it continued to move along fast enough for what it was, a luck-based family game with some agony and mild decision-making.

item.name: Das Amulett
item.comment: Way too unbalanced and susceptable to the inexperienced player giving the game away. Other than that I really love this game. It really needs a new set of well tested spells.

item.name: Andromeda
item.comment: Nice idea and presentation, but way too luck dependent. King of the I-got-no-strategy-but-what-the-heck-let's-just-shake-and-see-what-comes-out win.

item.name: Attila
item.comment: Always worth a play. Find someone who can handle the scoring and then everyone report in the same way: red up 2 in green.

item.name: Ave Caesar
item.comment: Game was actually published by Ravensburger. Top Race was put out by ASS.

item.name: Balmy Balloonists
item.comment: A real sleeper, at least that's what everyone thought they were or could have been doing. I liked it but it is very sedate.

item.name: Bamboleo
item.comment: Scoring the pieces based on weight is the way to go here.

item.name: Battle Cry
item.comment: Now this is a 2-player game.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: Lost Cities with action cards and the opportunity to actually contend with your opponent and not just the game.

item.name: Battlecards: World Conflict – North African Campaign – Starter Set
Battlecards: World Conflict – Pacific Theatre – Starter Set
Battlecards: World Conflict – The Russian Front – Starter Set
Battlecards: World Conflict – Western European Campaign – Starter Set
item.comment: I prefer multiplayer European style games where there is more interaction socially and within the game. Since I typically only get to play on "game day" with the group, I'd rather be involved in those games. That said, I am having more fun with this game every time I play it. While that won't happen all that often, I'm happy to add it to my collection as an inexpensive 2-player game with some depth to it, along the lines of Battlecry only in a much smaller box and faster to set up. Oh, and thanks, startune.

item.name: Bauernschlau
item.comment: Bluffing game with little depth. Definitely light family fare.

item.name: Bausack
item.comment: Great stacking game. Need a steady hand and table. Brings all kinds of gamers and nongamers together.

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: This is a very addicting game that everyone seems to take to right away. You do need 4 players to really enjoy it. If it worked equally well with 2 or even 3 players, then I would give it a 9 or 10.

item.name: The Bucket King
item.comment: I like this little filler. It's fluff but it's nice fluff. It moves up close to Frank's Zoo as one I'm willing to play to open, close or to simply take a laugh break.

item.name: El Caballero
item.comment: I liked this game well enough but scoring was difficult. For me the details you have to pick out and count were too small, especially as the game developed. Made things confusing. For me there needed to be Settler-size tiles, I guess.

item.name: Canasta Caliente
item.comment: $5 at Target... I'll give it a shot.

item.name: Capitol
item.comment: My favorite of the 3 that Moon and Weissblum put out this year. A well-balanced gamer's game that is always a tense contest.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: Sorry, Leo, but I still think this game is lame. Everyone sits around collecting cards and waiting for someone else to make the first moves. Lame.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: I finally played this at a recent convention with 5 players all for the first time. No one was overly thrilled with the experience, but at least 3 said they wanted to try it again with 3 or 4 players. With 5 it happened (and seemed likely to reoccur) that at least one player is out of contention early on due to scattered tiles that have little appeal to other players, and lack of essential business tiles at key times for exploitation.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: Always draws a crowd when brought out. If I leave it set up for people to play, it will go nonstop for the entire gaming session. Some problem with skill level differences.

item.name: Daytona 500
item.comment: Top Race is my favorite version because of the betting mechanic and the catch-up cards.

item.name: Democrazy
item.comment: One of the miserable Blue Box series of games that never should have been published. Not as miserable as most of the others. Take a single mechanic and make it into a game that lasts way to long.

item.name: A Dog's Life
item.comment: I do not understand Eurogames. A Dog's Life, like Evo, looked like it had a lot to offer. I found Evo dull and A Dog's Life lifeless.
item.conditiontext: My friend's dog ate one of the game pieces not essential to game play.

item.name: Draco & Co
item.comment: Never should have been published. More Blue Box trash. We couldn't even finish this one. You have so little that you can actually do in your turn but you are affected by what almost everyone else does on their turns. No control for me translates into helpless frustration. You get played and abused by this game so what's the point? Not

item.name: Dragon's Gold
item.comment: One of the better of the Blue Boxes but that's not saying much. We did make it all the way through this one (unlike Draco & Co.), but I'll never play it again.

item.name: Dschunke
item.comment: There's a big problem here. While you are doing blind auctions, you are using resource cards of which there are only 4 types. The cards are selected openly which favors those players who are able to track and remember those kinds of things. I can't, but my very good friend can. Kind of ruins it for me.

item.name: Dungeoneer: Tomb of the Lich Lord
item.comment: A real yawner. I would not recommend it for 2 players. (Or 3 to 4 for that matter.) So far though my reaction is similar to the one I had when playing Talisman, a feeling of being trapped in a dice driven game that was trying to entertain me but was failing. Slow to develop with just two players, it quickly becomes a contest to see who can kill off the other with Encounters first. Woe to the Warrior who fails to draw any supplemental Magic skill since so many of the Encounters, especially the more powerful ones, utilyze Magic attacks. Get a couple of them early on and you can quickly beat that dwarf into submission. Too much fiddling with cards and counters, and zero roleplaying. Had much more fun playing Piratenbucht and going "argh, ye thievin' pirate!"... It was somewhat better with 4 players (played x3), but game still seemed too fiddly and too long for the low level of decision-making and mild amount of fun derived from it. And there were a couple of gamers with a long, rich backgrounds in rpg's playing who I thought might really get a kick out of this game but it was a concensus "5", might play it again if someone else wants to but feel the time could be better spent playing a good European board game. In fact we went on to play Keythedral for the first time and Pampas Railways, both of which we all enjoyed immensely. I have to recommend you play this before you buy it. It is good for what it is; the Glory/Peril system is an excellent concept that virtually eliminates that bring down the leader problem that can plague games like this. It just didn't live up to all the hype this page is giving it.

item.name: Edel, Stein & Reich
item.comment: Great with 3 or 4 but no point in 5 players. The 4 possible choices when playing with 5 all too quickly drops to 2 when the gem pool becomes exhausted. And we're the first to notice this problem?

item.name: Elements
item.comment: I liked this game when I first played it. There were four of us gaming that night and this was introduced as a filler. We had a great time with it. It then took me almost a year to track down a copy of it. It seems none of the online stores are able to get it. I've played with 3, 4 and 5 players now and I prefer it with 4 or 5. I enjoy the higher level of competition.

item.name: Elfengold
item.comment: Worth it for the Wizard cards.

item.name: Europa 1945-2030
item.comment: A fun game of negotiations, alliances made and broken, but awful fiddly with layered board and all. Otherwise I would play it more and rate it higher.

item.name: Ever Green
item.comment: I played this for the first time 03/03. I had always been curious about it, it's a Kramer game after all. I'm glad I did, for the same reason I'm glad that I got to follow it up with Schrille Stille and Royal Turf, in a mixed group of gamers and non-gamers, 2 of them first timers to designer boards. We had a lot of fun!

item.name: Evo
item.comment: I've been increasingly disappointed Eurogames offerings. For me, Evo looked great, seemed to have interesting mechanics, but was not fun to play. Follow this with A Dog's Life and their many non-game Blue Box offerings, and well, I won't get fooled again. I'm amazed by how many people like this game. For me it was the beginning of the end. I will not buy another Descartes-Eurogames product.

item.name: Favoriten
item.comment: Fast, light horse racing of a different sort. Nice filler.

item.name: Forum Romanum
item.comment: Tough game. Very abstract. There is alot to keep track of on the board as people fill in rows, columns and rooms.

item.name: Fresh Fish
item.comment: Not impossible to buy... just expensive. One of Friese's best along with Funkenschlag. My wife and I enjoy both of these games and both are popular in our gaming group. Hey, the rules couldn't be that bad if I was able to figure them out. Worth the effort though. This is the game that sold me on Friese and keeps me looking to see what he will come up with next.

item.name: Galopp Royal
item.comment: Fun to bring out on occasion. Sedan chair racing, the true sport of kings.

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment: Got theme?

item.name: Gloria Picktoria
item.comment: As Reibach & Co.

item.name: Goldland
item.comment: This is one about which several of us really wanted to get excited being big fans of Kramer's work. Instead there is a concenses of mild disappointment. The more fiddly a game is, the better it has to be to justify or overcome the fiddliness. This one doesn't quite achieve this.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: Deserving of the term

item.name: Groo: The Game
item.comment: For fans of Groo. Get the expansion too.

item.name: Groo: The Game – Expansion Set
item.comment: Really helps the basic set.

item.name: Der Herr der Ringe: Die Gefährten – Das Kartenspiel
Hoity Toity
item.comment: You have to play this one with the right group. If one or two players turn off to it right away, you just can't change their mind. Try it later with a different bunch. It is the best of this rock-paper-scissors sort, but not everyone's cup of tea.

item.name: Im Schatten des Sonnenkönigs
item.comment: I've played it once so far. Definite improvements over Knights of the Rainbow. Worked well with 4 and new theme better supported.

item.name: Industrial Waste
item.comment: A well designed game. Perhaps we should not have played it after Puerto Rico and Funkenschlag, which offer so much more depth. It is more of a family game than the other two.

item.name: Landlord!
item.comment: I'm a big fan of Friese games and this one did not disappoint. It has a quirky theme that works and is well developed. There is plenty of interaction and even if mainly of the balance-the-game-by-sticking-it-to-the-leader type, the leader can cover himself by careful game play and by using some of his extra earnings to keep more cards which should afford him more protection. This also tends to prevent any runaway leader effect which I haven't seen in our games. To the contrary, our games have been close, the last one won by the player who appeared out of it through most of the game, but who managed to score over 50 points the last 2 turns while at the same time disrupting his opponents rentals. Plays great with 3 players.

item.name: Lumberjack
item.comment: Quick and light, but don't save it until the end of the night if you're really tired. Knocking the stack of logs down usually aborts the game. But if you can still manage a steady hand, it's fun with 3 and 4. There are not many decisions and none of them difficult. Mainly how not to set up your opponents to score, at least not without insuring you get to score as well. Different enough to be worth having around for a change of pace.

item.name: Mü & More
item.comment: The only problem I have with this game is the endgame, where your parner can sink you in a bring down the leader move for which there is no defense other than to not participate in the bidding.

item.name: Mystery Rummy: Al Capone and the Chicago Underworld
Mystery Rummy: Jack the Ripper
item.comment: I enjoy this most with 3 players.

item.name: Mystery Rummy: Murders in the Rue Morgue
New England
item.comment: Theme did not work for me at all. Seemed more like the Oklahoma land rush than some 100 odd settlers trying to survive their first winter in the new world. And where were the Native Americans without whom they would never had survived a second winter? Where'd the cows come from? That aside, the setup allows for real problems for the players placing their start tiles last. The different shapes for scoring in the 3 land development types is confusing, unnecessary and counter-intuitive. If the theme is a throwaway, you can't justify it that way. So why? Ultimately, it ends up being to predictable. You set yourself up to play the development cards then do small things to enhance your score and save your money until the cards you need show up. I did not find this interesting or challenging.

item.name: Nur Peanuts!
item.comment: Nur Peanuts is a just for fun family game with that

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment: I enjoyed this one along with the rest of my group, everyone rating it an 8 or 9, regardless of their fate. It is solidly in the family game bracket with the luck factor, but there is nothing wrong with that. It's incredibly fun allowing for all sorts of silliness. Yes, it's frustrating to get beaten by luck, whether from the dice or the cards, but fortunes change and next game it could be you with favorable winds filling your sails. I enjoyed the theme, thought it was well worked out. It is one of the few boards we have actually played twice in a session in a long time.

item.name: Pizarro & Co.
item.comment: My first play with 5 was confusing and frustrating. Enjoyed as a 3-player game. Theme is an overlay as is the case with too many European games.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: One of the best of the year.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: One of the best of the year.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: Download and laminate the player mats. While not essential to game play, they help to organise your bits and as a player aid to the different scoring methods.

item.name: Railroad Dice
item.comment: This is my initial rating after playing it with 4 and 2 players. Had it been shorter and cost significantly less, I might have rated it as high as 7. While the components are likely worth the cost, I'm not certain that the game is. It will have to generate a lot of replay to justify the expense and I'm not yet sure how that will go. Play - or lack there of - over the next few weeks will decide. And it has to compete with Power Grid and Age of Steam for table time, both of which are well worth the cost of admission and time to play.

item.name: San Gimignano
item.comment: This is a game that improves dramatically with repeated plays. Initially there is a tendency to be territorial, but then you realize that you don't have to stay in one area. Decisions become more difficult as you better recognize key guilds around the layout, offensive as well as defensive placements, and better yet, where it is possible to invade, put your opponent on the defensive and come away with another tower. The down side of any game of this type, where everyone is in everybody elses stuff, is the kingmaker aspect. Play this a few times before deciding.

item.name: San Marco
item.comment: A very good family/gamers game. Enough depth for the gamers along with rich, enjoyable game play for the family. Excellent replayability.

item.name: Santa Fe
item.comment: Quick to learn, this is a great family game for gamers.

item.name: Savannah Café
item.comment: mindless... too bad it's not mindless and fun...

item.name: Shark
item.comment: Played it the first time and could not begin to imagine why it was being picked up by RGGs. Played it again (with 3 players), getting the rules right this time, and had a great time. It was fun to see how the mechanics created the theme. Had an equally good time with 4 players.

item.name: Show Manager
item.comment: I hate this game. I do. I always get my arse handed to me. It is terribly annoying that everyone else seems to like it, especially the wives.

item.name: Starship Catan
item.comment: Broken by card counting.

item.name: Stock Car Championship Racing Card Game
Street Illegal
item.comment: Openning round was a 5. Second round a 6. Main problem is figuring out what to make of chips and temporary speed. Once you get past that -- and you'll probably need to read the FAQs, review all the examples and then ruminate on that information until a light comes on -- it will all seem so obvious. Then you'll just be faced with the task of getting others on board with you. I'm excited about the game but am having trouble getting others excited about it too. Fast & fun as a 2-player game; old pro's keep the pressure on you.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment: Okay, further play with different expectations has raised my opinion of this game. It does make a fun filler between more demanding games. Three rounds is about all it takes to finish a game, and this is usually enough to spread the luck around. I'll bring it along for a while on that basis.

item.name: TurfMaster
item.comment: I am upgrading my rating of this one. I enjoy it every time I get the opportunity to break it out. It is quick to teach, easily accomodates 6-8, and is engaging. I have always run the 3 race cycle and everyone seems to enjoy it to the end, regardless of the outcomes of the earlier races.

item.name: TurfMaster Course Collection 1
item.comment: Haven't used yet.

item.name: Villa Paletti
item.comment: Not my favorite game from Zoch but still a lot of fun.

item.name: Volldampf
item.comment: Repeated play has had me raise my rating of this one. Challenging game play, yet we are able to bring it out for family gaming. Close scores and come from behind victories keep this one exciting.

item.name: Who Stole Ed's Pants?
item.comment: This could be a Steve Jackson design/publication or a Eurogame Blue Box. Those of you who know me will understand this to be an insult as I do not favor those types of games. I find them chaotic and devoid of fun. Too often I found myself with cards I could not use. But as I swap out cards at the rate of 1 per turn, the situation on the table continues to change, with more players bringing more overall chaos and less control per player. I hated Draco & Co. for the exact same reason. There is a game here that works well enough that others actually seemed to enjoy it. I just wanted it to be over.

item.name: Wongar
item.comment: More confrontational than Tigris & Euphrates because you start with your forces intermixed, or at least you had better. A perverse mix of T&E and El Grande with a bit of Taj Mahal card management thrown in. Typical of a lot of Moon's designs, it lacks the overall elegance of these other 3 titles.

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment: I rather like these rummy-type games. I prefer his Jack the Ripper with 3 players and Murders in the Rue Morgue with 2 or partners.
